channel.title: aws-vault on Russell T Sherman
channel.description: Recent content in aws-vault on Russell T Sherman

item.title: aws-vault outputs `'aws_access_key_id'` message and does nothing
item.description: Question When calling aws-vault exec or using assume-role in geodesic, a single line is output that simply says: 'aws_access_key_id' Answer This is usually because there’s a [default] section in your ~/.aws/config. Remove that and it should start to work.

item.title: aws-vault: error: Failed to get credentials ... aes.KeyUnwrap(): integrity check failed.
item.description: Question When calling aws-vault exec or attempting to assume-role, I get the following error: Enter passphrase to unlock /conf/.awsvault/keys/: aws-vault: error: Failed to get credentials for peerstreet (source profile for cp-root-admin): aes.KeyUnwrap(): integrity check failed. Answer This horribly cryptic error message is a cryptographers way of saying “wrong password”. Just try running the command again, but this time enter the correct password. =)

item.title: aws-vault: error: Failed to start credential server
item.description: Question When running aws-vault or assume-role, I get the following error: aws-vault: error: Failed to start credential server: listen tcp 127.0.0.1:9099: bind: address already in use Answer This is usually caused by another geodesic shell running. This happens because aws-vault server can only be run once. Try exiting your other geodesic shell.
